item.title: No Country for Old Men, 2007 (contains spoilers)
item.description:
This review may contain spoilers.

idk but occassional sincere moments (Moss' water or sheriff and his wife etc.) make this movie so much. It could've easily ended up a nihilistic edgefest but it steered away juust enough to be hopeful and humane while keeping dreadful atmosphere.

second time watching, and anti-climax third act makes so much sense in denying audience catharsis. Violence erupts suddenly and suddenly it concludes. By forcing violence off-screen, survivors and audience are left only to ponder with its emotional consequences.

and that's exactly the spiritual punchline here - a soul crying out at inexplicable world. Characters describing Anton as "principled" over and over again is just their need to make sense of chaos of it all. Sheriff, defeated, realizes there isn't anything but chaos left (and never was), and that he was never one to do anything about it. So he reminisces when someone else had to hold that moral weight, and his was only to follow.
item.dc:creator: fedza

item.title: Everything Everywhere All at Once, 2022 (contains spoilers)
item.description:
This review may contain spoilers.

tl;dr variation on a theme, except theme is done already and it is done better, while your mileage on the "variation" may vary. it's fun at least

I think "multiverse" as a concept, counterintuitively, means writing yourself into a corner at one point or another. Any actual human character exposed to multiverse will inevitably go insane from possibilities or realize that they must settle for immediate pleasure of living in the present, mundane moment. Which is exactly why the "no spoiler" policy going around social media for this film is so puzzling for me - every single beat of Everything Everywhere is very predictable. Rick and Morty, It's such a beautiful day, Evangelion (and many more) more or less covered all themes present here more than 10 years ago, and arguably better. And how many "just enjoy your life :D" do we need? Apparently too many.

This leaves Everything Everywhere in an awkward conundrum, how to exactly iterate on the..."processed" formula while standing on its own feet? The answer is tryhard camp with at times insufferable earnestness. That camp certainly wasn't my type of camp - too much "lol random" moments with early internet/tumblr humor. In these irony poisoned times, it's weird to say that something is too honest. And it's a weakness here. Everything Everywhere's brand of earnestness is rejecting to learn from its ancestors and to be creative with the formula. Sadly, it drives head first into limp, tautological "everybody actually deserves some love" climax. Which is nigh dissapointing.

Scratch that. Multiverse as a concept is insidious as literally everything is possible. So why does Everything Everywhere dwell on like, four of universes? Singer, kung fu, other kung fu, hotdogs, rocks Evelyn? And why is every one of them played as one time joke, only to be dragged all the way back to the end (even in emotional climax?) Ironically this entire film and Evelyn are the same character. Promise of "everything" is so much that film must settle for some one possibility, leaving it feel like film didn't live up to the "what could've been". As such it is stuck in schizophrenia of old ideas and references jumbled together in an attempt to be creative or new.

Characters were kinda bad. Evelyn doesn't have any anchoring characteristic (challenge: describe her character besides "pragmatic but loving mother"), Joy we are plainly told is a mess but at no point do we see it, Evelyn's father is just an "easily dissapointed asian father figure" etc. Characters being underbaked also reflects on their relationships, which we are only ever told about. Emotional climax doesn't hit any of the emotional highs it's supposed to, we aren't even aware what exactly is conflict between Evelyn and Joy beside them being vaguely hostile to each other (related to Joy' sexuality among other, vaguely hinted to, things). To sum it, their relationship is very relatable on a symbolical level, but practically hollow.

Shining champion of Everything Everywhere is actually Waymond. Played off as goofy, soft spoken (opposed to aptly named Alfa version) husband he ends up a genuine hero. And he didn't transform, he just kept his biggest virtue - trying really hard. Evelyn realizing he was the mending force of her life was a great emotional moment for me.

Maybe not a valid criticism but I feel like a lot of opportunities are missed. All the generational conflicts are brushed off, even though there is a clear conflict based on tradition. I would've thought that movie about angry zoomer stumped with possibilities who doesn't believe in anything and is sad about it would've connected with me more. Dramatic conflict between putting yourself in a box of expectations (Evelyn and her father) and destroying every framework to feel free (Evelyn to her father and Joy to Evelyn) gets resolved with "we love each other vewy much!!" even though it's such a big thing in, like, human condition. Philosophy of this doesn't go much more far than your average reddit thread (they love rick and morty very much).

All in all...maybe I expected too much. This is nothing but a (technically) well done fun movie. Does it warrant any of the praise? Well, if you look at it as high profile blockbuster then yes. This is earnestness/humanity that Marvel could've been. But on a closer inspection it falls off as too lacking in any kind of nuance, and any number of kar-wai references can't fix that.
item.dc:creator: fedza

item.title: C'mon C'mon, 2021
item.description:
C'mon C'mon can't properly handle the irony of an 8(!) year old kid being crazily self aware while one of main themes of movie is "kids feel it when something bad is happening, but can't properly express it". As such, movie feels more or less insincere. Banking too much on "cute factor" and melodrama, plot threads that never resolve in any way (god forbid satisfying way), unnecessary b&w picture and overly repetitive plot points (thing happens, joaquin pheonix verbatim repeats what happens and adds completely unemotional thought like "damn that thing just happened...crazy") C'mon C'mon leads absolutely nowhere.

Even kid interviews for which movie justifies as "there are some perspectives everyone needs to hear" end up awfully one note and...insignificant, with motivational poster kind of message as "future is murky but we must press on" and "it's ok to not feel good sometimes". Which is exactly the kind of note this non-ending concludes with.

Through and through safe, boring and vapid hipster-baitish movie (performances are good).

ALSO THE KID IS A REDDITOR -10/10
item.dc:creator: fedza

item.title: The Princess Bride, 1987
item.description:
tl;dr didn't enjoy it that much (very funny at times), but it's great family movie.


Story is framed in weird way. Plot of Princess Bride is grandpa telling his sick grandson a fairy tale. For that reason, we are to take plot as exactly that, a fairy tale. Yet, plot is very self-aware about being formulaic, as grandson can't stop (correctly) predicting whichever happens - grandpa has no chance of creating suspense.

Thus, Princess Bride exists in a curious superposition between spoof and sincere. What bothered me is that it wasn't good enough in being either of those two.

If it were sincere, Princess Bride just isn't interesting enough. Action and setpieces were dull and visuals are not fulfilling of the "fairy tale" promise. Notice here that Princess Bride cost $40mil(!!). It doesn't have reason to feel like a low-budget spoof.

And yet, it isn't spoofy enough. I didn't have enough of occasional smart jokes, low-budget feel, self-awareness, bad action and insistent clichés. Is everyone ultra honorable (or ultra evil) because it's a fairy tale or because it's making fun of fairy tales? Phrase "true love" is uttered so many times it lost all meaning. At one point I got so lulled in that I was genuinely shocked at Inigo getting mortally wounded - too bad, security is returned by him being a-ok in next scene.

Is Princess Bride mocking anyone demanding more complex stories? Maybe acts as finger to all the deconstructions and ironic detachments to the genre, and shows genuine love for fairy tales as something comfy for everyone who was a kid at one point? Is presented predictability of fairy tales exact reason for their comfyness?

After writing all this out, I would just say it's good family movie, and my qualms don't apply for that purpose. Kids can enjoy it, and humor is mature enough for adults too.

=================================================================
TAKOĐE ZAŠTO TYRONE IZGLEDA ISTO KAO s̶u̶m̶p̶o̶r̶ GORDAN KIČIĆ

item.title: Black Mirror episodes ranked by "we live in a Society" factor
item.description:
"We live in a Society" factor is based on how (un)subtle the episode is, how much it mocks fucking normies (ree) and how likely it is to be liked by your futurphobic boomer parents. Also see: father I cannot click a book.

Check the notes for justifications.

Upon making the list I see that first 11 episodes (on list) have straight up point about Society, while others are dramas/thrillers exploring average individuals in near future. Crocodile and USS Callister feel like neither, and Playtest and Metalhead exists in their own worlds.
In my humble opinion entries 1-7 are in Society too much while other (8-11) are fine.

I didn't include the movie because I got the worst ending and never cared for more because it sucks ass.

NOTE: This doesn't reflect my general ranking of episodes. Just the Society part.

  1. Black Mirror: Nosedive

    I don't think this needs any explanation. Subtlety found horrifically butchered. Nosedive prime suspect.

  2. Black Mirror: Fifteen Million Merits

    Here's the thing with these kind of episodes taking place in a brutally on-the-nose allegories for late stage capitalism - they take themselves too seriously to the point of parody.
    Same thing with Nosedive, people are acting just too damn idiotic for this to be intelligent critique. And 15 million merits doesn't shy from laughing at its supposed audience - in this episode people are rude imbeciles only watching sub-60 iq shows and slaving away their lives.

  3. Black Mirror: White Bear

    Although I think lesson of this episode is extremely important, I'm not very happy with execution.

    People are shown as mindless sadists, and White Bear packs a lot more of "fate worse than death" than needed. Unnecessary 20 minute reiteration of its themes also makes me think White Bear is not very confident in its audience and/or Society.

  4. Black Mirror: Shut Up and Dance

    Plot of the episode itself I really like for reasons identical to National Anthem. Grounded in reality, having completely beliavable character motivations and reactions, Shut Up and Dance expresses genuine fear of present state of privacy with a fine thriller/drama.

    BUT...and this is a big "BUT..." ending cements it as one of the higher entries on this list.
    Firstly, unbeliavably dumb plot twist at the end that serves no purpose to theme of the episode (even is detrimental to it) and THEN somehow even dumber attempt at using "le meme culture" - probably just to drive home the point that writers are completely out of touch with contemporary/internet culture.

    It could've been a commentary on digital blackmailing and security, it could've been meditation on "for the lulz" philosophy, it could've been analysis of internet vigilantism, but ending cements it as none of the above whilst trying ALL of the above. Shut Up and Dance is thus made completely obsolete by National Anthem and White Bear.

  5. Black Mirror: Men Against Fire

    Ditto White Bear. Extremely important theme, but with 20 minute soliloquy explaining that idea because Black Mirror apparently thinks we are dumb. And again with "fate worse than death" scenario. Ol' reliable I guess.

  6. Black Mirror: Black Museum

    Ditto White Christmas. Just remove insightful commentary, add creepy-pasta level cruelty, shamelessly copy the structure and reference all older episodes.

    Clone of a clone of a clone of White Christmas.

  7. Black Mirror: Hated in the Nation

    Again, internet vigilantism.
    We live in a Society where people c̶a̶n̶c̶e̶l̶ kill other people.

  8. Black Mirror: The Waldo Moment

    I have no idea why is this episode hated so much. I can't even say it's "we live in a Society" as Waldo phenomenon unambigously happened in my country! And it portrays people somewhat sympathetically, they are just sick of being lied to.

  9. Black Mirror: Hang the DJ

    Very on-the-nose for dehumanizing instant relationships that hookup apps give. Good ending of Hang the DJ averts the "we live in a Society", as themes of the episode aren't insisting on everything being shit, but on contrary that technology can't kill true love. It feels maybe too honest for Black Mirror lol.

  10. Black Mirror: White Christmas

    Very similar feeling with White Bear, although admitedly this is a much better episode. I feel themes of this episode are important (commodity of being distanced from suffering that first world commodities cause, government power granted by contemporary technology etc) but it's a tad too "evil" for me to like.

    Psychological torture of first cookie and making culprit suffer for 100 years just so were juuust over the edge for me in terms of cruelty.
    Too bad White Christmas was only beggining. Last great episode imo.

...plus 9 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: fedza
